item.title: Fps arm+gloves
item.dc:creator: @Timberpig1 Timberpig.
item.description:
@Timberpig1 wrote:

no im just saying that im not used to seeing tris often in a model, now in zbrush, i model a model in 3ds, import and make awesome. then i can export and change the model into blocks rather than a hardcore mesh that would bog down render time.
i havent used zbush much, i think i opened it once or twice b4 school to play around with a model, but i havent gotten in depth with it yet

Read full topic

item.title: Fps arm+gloves
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Timberpig., post:39, topic:369692”]ahh i see.
everytime i come on here i get kinda choked up about talking about peoples models because as i’ve moved on to to Blender, and even further, (just got 3dsmax9 and Zbrush [ohh how i love torrents]) im used to not seeing triangles as most of my nowaday models are all quads:P
but yes, nice work :P[/quote]
You confused me. Triangles were all coplanar so it dont matter? As long as it. Reduced his polygons and wasn’t there for no reason. And zbrush works with tris doesn’t it?

Read full topic

item.title: Fps arm+gloves
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch2 Java Is My Bitch
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“dylan_0789, post:25, topic:369692”][quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=465819.msg3406917#msg3406917 date=1290383721]

[quote author=dylan_0789 link=topic=465819.msg3406896#msg3406896 date=1290382640]

Why the subsurfacing?

because gloves are smooth

Yes but for a simplistic model why not just self round? Subsurfacing isn’t always the best habit to get into.
[/quote]Actually if you’re modelling for movies and non-rsps type games, subsurfing is a good habit, as long as you know how to model without it aswell. My point is; I can do an equally (if not better) job subsurfing in waaayy less time.

You seem to be under the impression that subsurfing is bad, which is wrong, it’s put into every modeling program because it is extremely useful. Frell uses it, Tribb uses it, hell even pixar uses it (A hole shit ton too…).
Maybe it’s time that you open up to it too dylan.

Subsurfacing is great. Of course its used for movies. If you had seen my current project, trust me, you would retract this post. What I am saying is for a Runescape client model, it is less effective on the polygonal count. I subsurface my high-poly intended models too when necessary.
[/quote]Yea, this model wasn’t intended for the RS client.

Modified post to show criticism. My bad, I assumed it was for RS clients. I assume you didn’t post this at MITB because theres like 5 posts per week in the GFX section? :P[/quote]Yea lol

[quote=“dylan_0789, post:23, topic:369692”][quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=465819.msg3406841#msg3406841 date=1290379035]

Why the subsurfacing?

because gloves are smooth

Yes but for a simplistic model why not just self round? Subsurfacing isn’t always the best habit to get into.
[/quote]Actually if you’re modelling for movies and non-rsps type games, subsurfing is a good habit, as long as you know how to model without it aswell. My point is; I can do an equally (if not better) job subsurfing in waaayy less time.

You seem to be under the impression that subsurfing is bad, which is wrong, it’s put into every modeling program because it is extremely useful. Frell uses it, Tribb uses it, hell even pixar uses it (A hole shit ton too…).
Maybe it’s time that you open up to it too dylan.

Subsurfacing is great. Of course its used for movies. If you had seen my current project, trust me, you would retract this post. What I am saying is for a Runescape client model, it is less effective on the polygonal count. I subsurface my high-poly intended models too when necessary.

Criticism:
Not too bad. The overall design is actually pretty nice. One thing with subsurfacing: To prevent the ‘rounding’ on certain edges, select the edge and in the Transform Properties bump up the Median Crease. This will give the selected edge a pinkish line around it to show that there is a crease. Another option is Edge Split modifier which flattens out edges that ate above a certain angle, although this modifier doesn’t always overlap well with Subsurfacing. The polygon flow is decent in most parts. Just the base structure doesn’t look as well as it could. Although it is still acceptable as it is not too messy. Whats the render polygon count? I ask render as the render shows subsurfacing at level 2 as a default.[/quote]with the arm I’m making the render poly is 10k, I’m gunna bake it to a texture and make a lower poly version (or just use unsubsurfed version.) for the fps. My friend says that 6k polys is max for the main first person shooter’s arm. Where are the transform properties by the way?

Read full topic

because gloves are smooth

Yes but for a simplistic model why not just self round? Subsurfacing isn’t always the best habit to get into.

You seem to be under the impression that subsurfing is bad, which is wrong, it’s put into every modeling program because it is extremely useful. Frell uses it, Tribb uses it, hell even pixar uses it (A hole shit ton too…).
Maybe it’s time that you open up to it too dylan.

Subsurfacing is great. Of course its used for movies. If you had seen my current project, trust me, you would retract this post. What I am saying is for a Runescape client model, it is less effective on the polygonal count. I subsurface my high-poly intended models too when necessary.
[/quote]Yea, this model wasn’t intended for the RS client.[/quote]
Modified post to show criticism. My bad, I assumed it was for RS clients. I assume you didn’t post this at MITB because theres like 5 posts per week in the GFX section?

Read full topic

item.title: Fps arm+gloves
item.dc:creator: @dylan_0789 dylan_0789
item.description:
@dylan_0789 wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch, post:21, topic:369692”][quote author=dylan_0789 link=topic=465819.msg3406815#msg3406815 date=1290378038]

Why the subsurfacing?

because gloves are smooth

Yes but for a simplistic model why not just self round? Subsurfacing isn’t always the best habit to get into.
[/quote]Actually if you’re modelling for movies and non-rsps type games, subsurfing is a good habit, as long as you know how to model without it aswell. My point is; I can do an equally (if not better) job subsurfing in waaayy less time.

You seem to be under the impression that subsurfing is bad, which is wrong, it’s put into every modeling program because it is extremely useful. Frell uses it, Tribb uses it, hell even pixar uses it (A hole shit ton too…).
Maybe it’s time that you open up to it too dylan.[/quote]
Subsurfacing is great. Of course its used for movies. If you had seen my current project, trust me, you would retract this post. What I am saying is for a Runescape client model, it is less effective on the polygonal count. I subsurface my high-poly intended models too when necessary.

Criticism:
Not too bad. The overall design is actually pretty nice. One thing with subsurfacing: To prevent the ‘rounding’ on certain edges, select the edge and in the Transform Properties bump up the Median Crease. This will give the selected edge a pinkish line around it to show that there is a crease. Another option is Edge Split modifier which flattens out edges that ate above a certain angle, although this modifier doesn’t always overlap well with Subsurfacing. The polygon flow is decent in most parts. Just the base structure doesn’t look as well as it could. Although it is still acceptable as it is not too messy. Whats the render polygon count? I ask render as the render shows subsurfacing at level 2 as a default.

Yeah subsurfacing isn’t bad. Most companies use it. I would say the only company that doesn’t use it is JaGeX. :P. It makes a low poly model look very nice.

item.title: Fps arm+gloves
item.dc:creator: @Java_Is_My_Bitch2 Java Is My Bitch
item.description:
@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

[quote=“dylan_0789, post:20, topic:369692”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=465819.msg3406779#msg3406779 date=1290376513]

Why the subsurfacing?

because gloves are smooth
[/quote]
Yes but for a simplistic model why not just self round? Subsurfacing isn’t always the best habit to get into.[/quote]Actually if you’re modelling for movies and non-rsps type games, subsurfing is a good habit, as long as you know how to model without it aswell. My point is; I can do an equally (if not better) job subsurfing in waaayy less time.

You seem to be under the impression that subsurfing is bad, which is wrong, it’s put into every modeling program because it is extremely useful. Frell uses it, Tribb uses it, hell even pixar uses it (A hole shit ton too…).
Maybe it’s time that you open up to it too dylan.

Read full topic
